form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Cardin introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide for a progressive consumption tax and to reform the income tax, and for other purposes.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Progressive Consumption Tax Act of 2014.

Except as otherwise expressly provided, whenever in this Act an amendment or repeal is expressed in terms of an amendment to, or repeal of, a section or other provision, the reference shall be considered to be made to a section or other provision of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

subsection.text: Subtitle D is amended by inserting before chapter 31 the following new chapter:

toc.toc-entry: Subchapter E. Definitions and special rules

subsection.text: A tax is hereby imposed on every taxable supply.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), the amount of the tax shall be 10 percent of the taxable amount.
The amount of the tax shall be zero with respect to the provision of any supply which is—

subparagraph.text: a supply of tangible personal property that is exported from the United States within 90 days after the provider gives an invoice for the supply, or
a supply, other than a supply of tangible personal property—

clause.text: which is provided to a recipient that is not in the United States when the supply is performed or otherwise done, and
the use of which takes place outside of the United States.

subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter, the taxable amount for any taxable supply for which money is the only consideration shall be the price charged by the provider—

paragraph.text: including all invoiced charges for transportation, and other items payable to the provider with respect to the supply, but
excluding the tax imposed by section 3901 with respect to the supply and excluding any State and local sales and use taxes with respect to the supply.

subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter, the taxable amount for any taxable supply which includes consideration other than money shall be the fair market value of the consideration (including all invoiced charges for transportation and other items payable to the provider) plus the amount of any money paid in consideration.
For purposes of this chapter, the taxable amount in the case of any import shall be—

paragraph.text: the customs value plus customs duties and any other duties which may be imposed, or
if there is no such customs value, the fair market value (determined as if the importer had sold the supply).

subsection.continuation-text: For purposes of this subsection, the customs value of any import shall include all invoiced charges for transportation and other items payable to the importer with respect to the supply.

subsection.header: Special rule in the case of sales of certain used consumer goods
subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter, if—

paragraph.text: a person acquires any tangible personal property in a transaction which was not taxable under this chapter, and
such property had been used by an ultimate consumer before such acquisition,

subsection.continuation-text: the taxable amount in the case of any sale of such property by such person (determined without regard to this subsection) shall be reduced by the amount paid for such property by such person.

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 3912. Supplies made in connection with the United States.

subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter, the term taxable supply means—

paragraph.text: the importation of property into the United States, and
any supply (other than an exempt supply)—

subparagraph.text: which is provided—

clause.text: in the course of carrying on a trade or business,
in the case of an organization exempt from tax under section 501(a), in furtherance of the activities related to the purpose or function constituting the basis of its exemption under section 501, or

in the case of a State, an Indian tribal government, a possession of the United States, or any political subdivision of any of the foregoing, or the United States or the District of Columbia, in carrying out any activity that is not an essential governmental function,

subparagraph.text: for which consideration is provided in return, and
which is made in connection with the United States.

subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter—

paragraph.text: The term supply means any supply whatsoever, including—

subparagraph.text: the sale or provision (including through renting, leasing, or licensing) of property,
the performance of services,
the grant, assignment, or surrender of real property,
the creation, grant, transfer, assignment, or surrender of any right,
financial supplies, and
an entry into, or release from, an obligation or agreement to perform or refrain from performing an act.

paragraph.header: Special rule for services for employer
paragraph.text: An employee’s services for the employee’s employer shall not be treated as a supply.

section.header: Supplies made in connection with the United States

subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter—

paragraph.text: The supply of tangible property is made in connection with the United States if—

subparagraph.text: the property is delivered or made available to the recipient in the United States, or
the property is assembled in or removed from any location in the United States.

paragraph.text: The supply of real property is made in connection with the United States if the real property is located in the United States.

subsection.header: Services, intangible property, and other supplies
subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter, the supply of anything other than tangible property or real property is made in connection with the United States if—

paragraph.text: the supply is used, performed, or otherwise done in the United States, or
the supply is provided through a trade or business in the United States.

subsection.text: An exempt supply shall not be subject to tax under this chapter.
For purposes of this chapter—

paragraph.text: The term exempt supply means—

subparagraph.text: the rental or leasing of residential real property,
any sale of qualified residential real property,
any financial supply, and
any taxable supply (or category of such supplies) treated as an exempt supply under section 3932(b).

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1), the term qualified residential real property means residential real property—

subparagraph.text: which—

clause.text: has previously been sold as residential real property, or
has been continuously rented for 5 years or more, and

subparagraph.text: to which substantial renovations have not been made after the date of the enactment of this chapter.

subsection.text: There shall be allowed as a credit against the aggregate amount of tax imposed by section 3901 with respect to all taxable supplies made by the taxpayer during the taxable period an amount equal to the aggregate amount of tax imposed by section 3901 on creditable acquisitions of the taxpayer during such taxable period.
For purposes of this chapter, the term creditable acquisition means the acquisition or receipt of any supply—

paragraph.text: which was subject to tax under section 3901 at the time it was provided to the taxpayer,
which was used by the taxpayer—

subparagraph.text: in the course of carrying on a trade or business,
in the case of a taxpayer exempt from tax under section 501(a), in furtherance of the activities related to the purpose or function constituting the basis of the exemption under section 501, or

in the case of a State, an Indian tribal government, a possession of the United States, or any political subdivision of any of the foregoing, or the United States or the District of Columbia, in carrying out any activity that is not an essential governmental function, and

paragraph.text: which was not used by the taxpayer to make an exempt supply.

subsection.text: If supplies are used partly for a use described in subsection (b)(2) and partly for another use, the credit shall be allowable only with respect to the supplies used as described in subsection (b)(2).

paragraph.text: If for any taxable period the amount of the credit allowable by subsection (a) exceeds the aggregate amount of the tax imposed by section 3901 for such period, such excess shall be treated as an overpayment of the tax imposed by section 3901.
Any overpayment under paragraph (1) for any taxable period shall be treated as arising on the later of—

subparagraph.text: the due date for the return for such period, or
the date on which the return is filed.

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 3923. Time for filing return and claiming credit; deposits of tax.
Sec. 3924. Treatment of related businesses, etc.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b), the person providing the supply shall be liable for the tax imposed by section 3901.
The person receiving the supply shall be liable for the tax imposed under section 3901—

paragraph.text: in the case of any taxable supply described in section 3911(a)(1), and
in the case of any taxable supply which is not a supply of tangible property and which is—

subparagraph.text: performed or otherwise done outside the United States,
used in the United States, and
acquired for use—

clause.text: in carrying on a trade or business in the United States,
by an organization exempt from tax under section 501(a), in furtherance of activities related to the purpose or function constituting the basis of its exemption under section 501, or

by a State, an Indian tribal government, a possession of the United States, or any political subdivision of any of the foregoing, or the United States or the District of Columbia, in carrying out any activity that is not an essential governmental function.

paragraph.header: Supplies made in connection with the United States
paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, any person providing a taxable supply shall give the recipient a tax invoice with respect to such supply.

paragraph.header: Certain services performed outside the United States
paragraph.text: In the case of any taxable supply described in section 3921(b)(2), paragraph (1) shall not apply and the person receiving the taxable supply shall generate a tax invoice with respect to such supply.

In the case of any taxable supply described in section 3911(a), the Secretary, in consultation with the Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection, shall promulgate regulations governing the provision of tax invoices.

subsection.text: The tax invoice required by subsection (a) with respect to any supply shall set forth—

paragraph.text: the name and, in the case of an invoice under subsection (a)(1), identification number of the provider,
the name of the recipient,
the date of the taxable supply,
the taxable amount with respect to the taxable supply,
the amount of the tax imposed by section 3901, and
such other information as may be prescribed by regulations.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) or (3), a taxpayer may claim a credit with respect to a creditable acquisition only if the taxpayer—

subparagraph.text: has in the taxpayer's possession a tax invoice which meets the requirements of this section, and
is named as the recipient of the supply in such invoice.

paragraph.header: Employees or other agents named in invoices
paragraph.text: To the extent provided in regulations, the naming of an employee or other agent of the recipient of the supply shall be treated as the naming of the recipient.

paragraph.header: Waiver of invoice requirement in certain cases
paragraph.text: To the extent provided in regulations, paragraph (1) shall not apply—

subparagraph.text: where the taxpayer can demonstrate that the failure to receive or to have in the taxpayer’s possession a tax invoice was without fault on the taxpayer's part, or
to a taxable supply (or category of supplies) where—

clause.text: the amount involved is de minimis, or
the information required by subsection (b) can be reliably established by sampling or by another method and can be adequately documented.

subsection.text: Any invoice required to be furnished by subsection (a) with respect to any supply shall be furnished not later than 15 business days after the tax point for such supply.

section.header: Time for filing return and claiming credit; deposits of tax

subsection.text: Before the last day of the fourth week (third week, in the case of any taxpayer to which subsection (c)(2) applies) after the close of each taxable period, each person liable for tax under this chapter shall file a return of the tax imposed by section 3901 on taxable supplies having a tax point within such taxable period.

subsection.header: Credit allowed for taxable period in which recipient receives invoice

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), a credit allowable by section 3916 with respect to a supply may be allowed only for the first taxable period by the close of which the taxpayer—

subparagraph.text: has paid or accrued amounts properly allocable to the tax imposed by section 3901 with respect to such supply, and
has a tax invoice (or equivalent) with respect to such supply.

paragraph.text: Under regulations, a credit allowable by section 3916 may be allowed for a period after the period set forth in paragraph (1).

subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter—

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), the term taxable period means a calendar quarter.

subparagraph.text: In the case of a taxpayer who makes taxable supplies for any month in excess of $20,000,000, the term taxable period means a calendar month.
If the taxpayer so elects, the term taxable period means a calendar month.

subsection.text: For purposes of this chapter—

paragraph.header: Chapter 1 rules with respect to provider govern
paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), the tax point for any supply is the earlier of—

subparagraph.text: the time (or times) when any income from the provision of the supply should be treated by the provider as received or accrued (or any loss should be taken into account by the seller) for purposes of chapter 1, or
the time (or times) when the provider receives payment for the sale.

paragraph.text: In the case of the importing of property, the tax point is when the property is entered, or withdrawn from warehouse, for consumption in the United States.

subsection.text: To the extent provided in regulations, monthly deposits may be required of the estimated liability for any taxable period for the tax imposed by section 3901.

section.text: For purposes of this chapter, to the extent provided in regulations, the taxpayer may elect—

paragraph.text: to treat as 1 person 2 or more businesses which may be treated under section 52(b) as 1 employer, and
to treat as separate persons separate divisions of the same business.

section.text: The Secretary shall submit to Congress semi-annual reports on the implementation and administration of this chapter, including the amount of revenue collected from the tax imposed under this chapter and estimates of the revenue to be collected from such tax for future period.
The Secretary shall prescribe such regulations as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter.

paragraph.text: The term business includes—

subparagraph.text: a trade, and
an activity regularly carried on for profit.

paragraph.text: The term business day means any day other than Saturday and Sunday and other than a legal holiday (within the meaning of section 7503).
The term employee has the meaning such term has for purposes of chapter 24.

The term financial supplies means the provision, acquisition, or disposal of any of the following: a bank account, a debit or credit arrangement, a mortgage, a superannuation fund, an annuity, insurance, a financial guarantee, an indemnity, currency, securities, or derivatives.
The term person includes any governmental entity.
The term provide, when used in reference to taxable supplies (other than in section 3911(a)(2)), includes the importation of property and the term provider includes the importer of property.
The term United States, when used in a geographical sense, includes a Commonwealth and any possession of the United States.

subsection.text: For purposes of subtitle A—

paragraph.text: Any credit allowable to a taxpayer under section 3916 which is attributable to any supply shall be treated as a reduction in the amount paid or incurred by the taxpayer for such supply.
The amount allowable as a deduction for the tax imposed by section 3901 shall be determined without regard to any credit allowable under section 3916.
For purposes of sections 613 and 613A—

subparagraph.text: gross income shall be reduced by the amount of the tax imposed by section 3901, and
taxable income shall be determined without regard to any deduction allowed for such tax.

subsection.header: Authority to zero rate de minimis supplies, etc
subsection.text: The Secretary may prescribe regulations treating as an exempt supply any taxable supply (or category of such supplies) where—

paragraph.text: the amount involved is de minimis, or
the revenue raised by taxing the supply is not sufficient to justify the administrative and other costs involved in the payment and collection of the tax.

Section 32 is amended to read as follows:
In the case of an eligible taxpayer, there shall be allowed as a credit against the tax imposed by this subtitle for the taxable year an amount equal to the sum of—

paragraph.text: the earned income amount (as determined under subsection (b)),
the child benefit amount (as determined under subsection (c)), plus
the additional child benefit amount (as determined under subsection (d)).

In the case of an eligible taxpayer (other than a head of a household as defined in section 2(b)) who is not filing a joint return for the taxable year under section 6013, the earned income amount shall be equal to—

subparagraph.text: in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income for the taxable year does not exceed $6,100, 25.1 percent of such earned income,
in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income for the taxable year exceeds $6,100 but does not exceed $9,000, $1,530 plus 17.1 percent of such earned income in excess of $6,100,

in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income (or, if greater, adjusted gross income) for the taxable year exceeds $9,000, but does not exceed $49,494, $2,025 minus 5 percent of such earned income or adjusted gross income in excess of $9,000, or
in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income (or, if greater, adjusted gross income) for the taxable year exceeds $49,494, $0.

paragraph.text: In the case of an eligible taxpayer who is a head of a household (as defined in section 2(b)), the earned income amount shall be equal to—

subparagraph.text: in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income for the taxable year does not exceed $9,150, 25.1 percent of such earned income,
in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income for the taxable year exceeds $9,150 but does not exceed $13,500, $2,294 plus 17.1 percent of such earned income in excess of $9,150,

in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income (or, if greater, adjusted gross income) for the taxable year exceeds $13,500, but does not exceed $74,241, $3,037 minus 5 percent of such earned income or adjusted gross income in excess of $13,500, or
in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income (or, if greater, adjusted gross income) for the taxable year exceeds $74,241, $0.

paragraph.text: In the case of an eligible taxpayer filing a joint return under section 6013, the earned income amount shall be determined pursuant to paragraph (1), except that the dollar amounts in effect under such paragraph shall be multiplied by 2.
In the case of an eligible taxpayer with a qualifying child, the child benefit amount shall be equal to 15 percent of the earned income of such taxpayer for the taxable year.

subparagraph.header: Limitation based on number of children
subparagraph.text: The child benefit amount determined under paragraph (1) shall not exceed an amount equal to the product of—

clause.text: the number of qualifying children of the taxpayer, multiplied by

subparagraph.header: Reduction based on earnings or adjusted gross income
subparagraph.text: The child benefit amount determined under this subsection (as determined after application of subparagraph (A)) shall be reduced (but not below zero) by an amount equal to 5 percent of the earned income (or, if greater, the adjusted gross income) of the taxpayer for the taxable year in excess of $75,000 ($110,000 in the case of a joint return).

paragraph.text: In the case of an eligible taxpayer with a qualifying child, the additional child benefit amount shall be equal to—

subparagraph.text: in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income for the taxable year does not exceed $20,000, the applicable percentage of such earned income,
in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income exceeds $20,000 but does not exceed $25,000, the applicable percentage of $20,000,
in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income (or, if greater, adjusted gross income) exceeds $25,000 but does not exceed the applicable amount, an amount equal to—

clause.text: the applicable percentage of $20,000, minus
15 percent of such earned income or adjusted gross income in excess of $25,000, or

subparagraph.text: in the case of a taxpayer whose earned income (or, if greater, adjusted gross income) exceeds the applicable amount, $0.

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1), the applicable percentage is—

subparagraph.text: in the case of a taxpayer with 1 qualifying child, 11 percent,
in the case of a taxpayer with 2 qualifying children, 17 percent, and
in the case of a taxpayer with 3 or more qualifying children, 19 percent.

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1), the applicable amount is—

subparagraph.text: in the case of a taxpayer with 1 qualifying child, $39,667,
in the case of a taxpayer with 2 qualifying children, $47,667, and
in the case of a taxpayer with 3 or more qualifying children, $50,333.

paragraph.text: The term eligible taxpayer means an individual—

subparagraph.text: whose principal place of abode is in the United States for more than one-half of such taxable year, and
is not a dependent (as defined under section 152) to another taxpayer for any taxable year beginning in the same calendar year as such taxable year.

paragraph.text: If an individual is the qualifying child of a taxpayer for any taxable year of such taxpayer beginning in a calendar year, such individual shall not be treated as an eligible taxpayer for any taxable year of such individual beginning in such calendar year.

paragraph.header: Exception for taxpayer claiming benefits under section 911
paragraph.text: The term eligible taxpayer does not include any taxpayer who claims the benefits of section 911 for the taxable year.

paragraph.header: Limitation on eligibility of nonresident aliens
paragraph.text: The term eligible taxpayer shall not include any individual who is a nonresident alien individual for any portion of the taxable year unless such individual is treated for such taxable year as a resident of the United States for purposes of this chapter by reason of an election under subsection (g) or (h) of section 6013.
No credit shall be allowed under this section to an eligible taxpayer who does not include on the return of tax for the taxable year—

subparagraph.text: such individual's taxpayer identification number, and
if the individual is married (within the meaning of section 7703), the taxpayer identification number of such individual's spouse.

paragraph.header: Taxpayers who do not include TIN, etc., of any qualifying child
paragraph.text: No credit shall be allowed under this section to any eligible taxpayer who has one or more qualifying children if no qualifying child of such taxpayer is taken into account under subsection (c) or (d) by reason of subsection (f)(4).

paragraph.header: Treatment of military personnel stationed outside of the United States
paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1)(A) and subsection (f)(3), the principal place of abode of a member of the Armed Forces of the United States shall be treated as in the United States during any period during which such member is stationed outside the United States while serving on extended active duty with the Armed Forces of the United States. For purposes of the preceding sentence, the term extended active duty means any period of active duty pursuant to a call or order to such duty for a period in excess of 90 days or for an indefinite period.

subparagraph.text: In the case of an individual who is married (within the meaning of section 7703), this section shall apply only if a joint return is filed for the taxable year under section 6013.

In the case of taxpayer filing a joint return under section 6013, such taxpayer shall not be treated as an eligible taxpayer for purposes of this section unless either the taxpayer or the taxpayer's spouse satisfies each of the requirements under this subsection.

paragraph.text: The term qualifying child means a qualifying child of the taxpayer (as defined in section 152(c), determined without regard to paragraph (1)(D) thereof and section 152(e)).

The term qualifying child shall not include an individual who is married as of the close of the eligible taxpayer's taxable year unless the individual qualifies as a dependent (as defined under section 152) of the taxpayer for such taxable year.
For purposes of paragraph (1), the requirements of section 152(c)(1)(B) shall be met only if the principal place of abode is in the United States.

subparagraph.text: A qualifying child shall not be taken into account under subsection (c) or (d) unless the taxpayer includes the name, age, and TIN of the qualifying child on the return of tax for the taxable year.
The Secretary may prescribe other methods for providing the information described in subparagraph (A).

paragraph.text: The term earned income means—

subparagraph.text: wages, salaries, tips, and other employee compensation, but only if such amounts are includible in gross income for the taxable year, plus

the amount of the taxpayer's net earnings from self-employment for the taxable year (within the meaning of section 1402(a)), but such net earnings shall be determined with regard to the deduction allowed to the taxpayer by section 164(f).

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1)—

subparagraph.text: no amount received as a pension or annuity shall be taken into account,
no amount to which section 871(a) applies (relating to income of nonresident alien individuals not connected with United States business) shall be taken into account,
no amount received for services provided by an individual while the individual is an inmate at a penal institution shall be taken into account,

no amount described in paragraph (1) received for service performed in work activities as defined in paragraph (4) or (7) of section 407(d) of the Social Security Act to which the taxpayer is assigned under any State program under part A of title IV of such Act shall be taken into account, but only to the extent such amount is subsidized under such State program, and
a taxpayer may elect to treat amounts excluded from gross income by reason of section 112 as earned income.

subsection.header: Taxable year must be full taxable year
subsection.text: Except in the case of a taxable year closed by reason of the death of the eligible taxpayer, no credit shall be allowable under this section in the case of a taxable year covering a period of less than 12 months.
For purposes of—

subsection.header: Amount of credit To be determined under tables
subsection.text: The amount of the credit allowed by this section shall be determined under tables prescribed by the Secretary.

subsection.header: Denial of credit for individuals having excessive investment income

paragraph.text: No credit shall be allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year if the aggregate amount of disqualified income of the taxpayer for the taxable year exceeds $5,000.
For purposes of paragraph (1), the term disqualified income means—

subparagraph.text: interest or dividends to the extent includible in income for the taxable year,
interest received or accrued during the taxable year which is exempt from tax imposed by this chapter,
the excess (if any) of—

clause.text: gross income from rents or royalties not derived in the ordinary course of a trade or business, over
the sum of—

subclause.text: the deductions (other than interest) which are clearly and directly allocable to such gross income, plus
interest deductions properly allocable to such gross income,

subparagraph.text: the capital gain net income (as defined in section 1222) of the taxpayer for such taxable year, and
the excess (if any) of—

clause.text: the aggregate income from all passive activities for the taxable year (determined without regard to any amount included in earned income under subsection (f) or described in a preceding subparagraph), over
the aggregate losses from all passive activities for the taxable year (as so determined).

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (2)(E), the term passive activity has the meaning given such term by section 469.
In the case of any taxable year beginning after 2015, each of the dollar amounts in subsections (b), (c), (d), and (j)(1) shall each be increased by an amount equal to—

subparagraph.text: such dollar amount, multiplied by

the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, determined by substituting calendar year 2014 for calendar year 1992 in subparagraph (B) thereof.

paragraph.text: If any dollar amount in subsections (b), (c), (d), and (j)(1), after being increased under paragraph (1), is not a multiple of $100, such dollar amount shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $100.

subsection.header: Restrictions on taxpayers who improperly claimed credit in prior year

paragraph.header: Taxpayers making prior fraudulent or reckless claims

subparagraph.text: No credit shall be allowed under this section for any taxable year in the disallowance period.
For purposes of subparagraph (A), the disallowance period is—

clause.text: the period of 10 taxable years after the most recent taxable year for which there was a final determination that the taxpayer's claim of credit under this section was due to fraud, and

the period of 2 taxable years after the most recent taxable year for which there was a final determination that the taxpayer's claim of credit under this section was due to reckless or intentional disregard of rules and regulations (but not due to fraud).

paragraph.text: In the case of a taxpayer who is denied credit under this section for any taxable year as a result of the deficiency procedures under subchapter B of chapter 63, no credit shall be allowed under this section for any subsequent taxable year unless the taxpayer provides such information as the Secretary may require to demonstrate eligibility for such credit.

title.header: Refund of excess consumption tax revenue

section.header: Refunds of excess consumption tax revenue

subsection.text: Subchapter B of chapter 65 is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

section.header: Refunds of excess consumption tax revenue

subsection.text: In the case of any qualifying excess consumption tax revenue year, the Secretary shall pay to each eligible filer an amount equal to the consumption tax refund amount.

subsection.header: Qualifying excess consumption tax revenue year
subsection.text: For purposes of this section—

paragraph.text: The term qualifying excess consumption tax revenue year means any calendar year for which the net consumption tax revenues exceed 10 percent of gross domestic product for such year.
The net consumption tax revenues for any calendar year shall be the excess of—

subparagraph.text: the tax imposed under section 3901 with respect to taxable supplies the tax point for which is during such calendar year, over
the credits allowed under section 3916 for such calendar year.

paragraph.text: The gross domestic product for any calendar year shall be the last estimate of the gross domestic product for such calendar year by the Department of Commerce which is published before the date that is 3 months after the close of such calendar year.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section—

subparagraph.text: The term eligible filer means, with respect to any qualifying excess consumption tax revenue year, any individual (other than an individual described in paragraph (2)) who filed a return of income tax for the individual's qualifying rebate taxable year.
The term eligible filer shall not include—

clause.text: any nonresident alien individual,
any individual who is a dependent (as defined in section 152) of another taxpayer for the individual's qualifying rebate taxable year, or
an estate or trust.

paragraph.text: The term qualifying rebate taxable year means, with respect to any individual in connection with a qualifying excess consumption tax revenue year, the taxable year of such individual which contains 6 or more months of such qualifying excess consumption tax revenue year.

subparagraph.text: An individual shall not be treated as an eligible filer for any year unless such individual includes on the return of tax for such year—

clause.text: such individual's valid identification number,
in the case of a joint return, the valid identification number of such individual's spouse, and
the valid identification number of any qualifying child (as defined in section 32(f)) claimed on such return.

subparagraph.text: For purposes of subparagraph (A), the term valid identification number means a social security number issued to an individual by the Social Security Administration. Such term shall not include a TIN issued by the Internal Revenue Service.

subparagraph.header: Special rule for members of the Armed Forces
subparagraph.text: Subparagraph (A) shall not apply to a joint return where at least 1 spouse was a member of the Armed Forces of the United States at any time during the taxable year.

paragraph.text: The consumption tax refund amount for any eligible filer for any qualifying excess consumption tax year shall be the product of—

subparagraph.text: the applicable amount, times
the applicable shares of the eligible filer.

paragraph.text: The applicable amount for any qualifying excess revenue consumption tax year is an amount equal to—

subparagraph.text: the excess described in subsection (b)(1), divided by
the total number of applicable shares of all eligible filers for such year.

paragraph.text: The number of applicable shares for any eligible filer shall be the sum of—

subparagraph.text: 1 (2 in the case of a joint return), plus
½ of the number of qualifying children (as defined in section 32(f)) claimed on the eligible filer's return for the filer's qualifying rebate taxable year.

subsection.text: Payments under subsection (a) shall be made as soon as practical after the Secretary has determined the consumption tax refund amount.
